name: 90s Extreme Skiing
extraInfo: Pro features 1.5x supersampling, resulting in a sharper image compared to base PS5. This also virtually eliminates shimmering, which is particularly noticeable in the distance. While the exact resolution and framerate haven't been confirmed, the more basic art style, as well as supersampling now being implemented, suggests it's likely rendering at the PSVR2 panel's highest resolution and refresh rate.

name: Alan Wake 2
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1224p to 4K PSSR/FSR. Mostly stable 30fps with RT reflections.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR/FSR at a locked 40fps. Combines the RT of the quality mode with image settings of performance. Requires 120hz display.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR/FSR. Mostly stable 60fps (lows of 50fps) with no RT. Graphics settings of base PS5 quality mode (more foliage/better lighting etc).

extraInfo: Can toggle between PSSR and FSR for upscaling. FSR is less noisy and more 4K like in stills. PSSR looks sharper in motion with less artifacting. Differences are less obvious in quality mode as base resolution is 1224p (others look relatively soft regardless as 864p to 4K is a big jump). There's no RT on base PS5 and Pro's quality mode also has higher quality shadows, volumetric lighting and fog. Both modes have a more stable framerate than their base PS5 counterparts.

name: Apex Legends

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Targets 4K at 60fps with high visual quality. In practice, the fidelity/quality mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Targets 1080p at 120fps with reduced visual quality.

extraInfo: These 2 modes are also on base PS5, but Pro hits the target framerate more often than their base PS5 counterparts. Interestingly, Apex Legends doesn't follow the standard naming convention as there's actually no fidelity/graphics mode.

name: Arken Age

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4096p per eye at 60fps re-projected.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 2240p per eye at 90fps native (no-reprojection).

extraInfo: Developers recommend the performance mode, likely due to the native motion. Base PS5 resolutions are 2432p in quality mode and 2048p in performance mode (framerates remain the same).

name: Arma Reforger

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1944p to 4K FSR 1 at a nearly locked 30fps. Has better ambient occlusion, enabled contact shadows, shadows on terrain surfaces, and improved cloud quality compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K FSR 1 at a relatively unstable 60fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 is exactly the same, but at 1620p and 1080p respectively. Performance mode has a decent amount of screen tearing. You can add an FPS counter to the HUD.

name: Asphalt Legends Unite

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K native at up to 120fps. Usually around 90fps with VRR during racing.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: DRS that reaches up to native 4K at a locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Pro performance mode's dynamic resolutions scaling doesn't dip very far from 4K in order to maintain 120fps. Hard to tell a difference unless looking at modes side-by-side.

name: Assassin's Creed Mirage
extraInfo: Through PSSR, Pro combines the 4K resolution, better shadows/reflections, higher texture resolution, and improved draw distance seen in the base PS5 30fps quality mode, with the 60fps seen in base PS5 performance mode. The framerate is also a nearly locked 60fps and more stable than base PS5 performance mode.

name: Assassin's Creed Shadows
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination and reflections

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Around 1584p DRS to 4K TAAU/PSSR at a mostly locked 30fps. Has both RT reflections and RTGI throughout open world. Higher quality draw distances, foliage density, shadows, textures, hair quality etc than performance mode.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Around 1440p DRS to 4K TAAU/PSSR at a stable 40fps with RT reflections (PSSR only) and RTGI (both upscalers). Graphical settings straddle between quality and performance modes (shadows of performance mode, hair strands of quality mode etc).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Around 1080p DRS to 4K TAAU/PSSR at a stable 60fps (lows of low 50s). No RT reflections, but RTGI remains throughout the world.

extraInfo: You can toggle between PSSR and TAAU as the upscaler. PSSR is a little softer, but much more stable with less aliasing/shimmer and TAAU's foliage/SSR is especially grainy. All this is then exacerbated in motion. PSSR fails to hit target framerate as often (usually around 4-8 fewer when it does drop), but still remains in the VRR window. RTGI is far more important to image quality than reflections. Base PS5 performance mode only has RTGI in the hideout, making Pro performance mode a generational leap due to the improved lighting across the map. There's also no RT reflections on base PS5.

name: Astro Bot
extraInfo: 1368p-1872p DRS to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps. Pro is more often in the higher bounds of the DRS. Despite Pro's DRS regularly having a lower base resolution than base PS5, the Pro's PSSR upscaling is cleaner/sharper with less aliasing compared to the TAA on base PS5, but also noisier (especially SSR) and more unstable. The introduced noise isn't particularly visible at normal viewing distances however.

name: Atomfall
rtTypes: Ray traced soft shadows (obscurance fields setting on PC)
extraInfo: Pro has DRS, but can render a full 4K at a locked 60fps. Whereas base PS5 renders a maximum of 1800p. However, both have a low of 1440p and neither hit their top resolution most of the time. All versions are also poorly aliased (even PC), so resolution differences are less noticeable than in other games because there's so much shimmer/jaggies regardless. There's also low resolution surfaces and very poor SSR (equivalent to PC low settings) that exacerbate the shimmer. Finally, the overkill AO (including the RT) overly silhouettes the image (especially characters) and can't be turned off.

name: Avatar: Pandora Frontiers
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and global illumination

modes.name: quality pro
modes.description: 900p-1152p DRS at mostly stable 60fps.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Sharper than quality pro (1512p-1800p DRS) but at locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Visual quality downgraded compared to quality but now at locked 40fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Lowest visual quality of all modes. Usually 936p DRS at nearly locked 60fps compared to base PS5 at 720p DRS with a less stable 60fps.

extraInfo: All modes can use either PSSR or FSR3 for upscaling to 4K. FSR is less noisy and looks sharper in stills. PSSR is less stable but sharper and clearer in motion. PSSR works best with the quality 30fps mode. Quality/balanced/performance are all the legacy modes from base PS5, but will run at the higher DRS bounds (1800p for quality etc) more often due to the Pro's extra power.

name: Baldur's Gate 3

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at nearly locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a mostly stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Pro performance mode looks better than even base PS5 quality mode due to upscalers used. PSSR is a bit softer than base PS5's FSR, but much more stable with less artifacting/flicker. This is especially seen in motion like moving shadows. Pro also has around a 10% higher framerate, so runs at 60fps more often than base PS5. Split screen can now run at either 30fps or 60fps.

name: Biped
extraInfo: Biped has no display options, so things like an 120fps mode are not available. However, Pro at least maintains a locked 60fps. Pro renders a 1440p image compared to base PS5's more 1080p-like image. The difference can be quite noticeable on things like railings where there's more jaggies on base PS5.

name: Biped 2
extraInfo: *Biped 2 isn't out until Q3 2025 (potentially September 30), but the following Biped 1 information should give us at least a good base of what to expect - 'Biped has no display options, so things like an 120fps mode are not available. However, Pro at least maintains a locked 60fps. Pro renders a 1440p image compared to base PS5's more 1080p-like image. The difference can be quite noticeable on things like railings where there's more jaggies on base PS5.'

name: Black Myth: Wukong
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen software-based global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1296p to 4K PSSR at a very stable 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1296p to 4K PSSR at a very stable 40fps on 120hz screens or 45fps on 60hz. Lower resolution shadows than quality mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p to 1440p FSR3. Frame-gen used to target a still unstable 60ps.

extraInfo: Unlike most Pro games, PSSR isn't much noisier than FSR and offers the clearest image. Base PS5 performance mode is very similar to the Pro and also uses frame generation. However due to frame gen, the quality/balanced modes have less input lag and therefore feel more responsive despite fewer frames. Base PS5 balanced and quality modes only target an upscaled 1440p and use non-frame gen FSR as its upscaler.

name: Blades Of Fire
extraInfo: Both PS5 consoles cap the framerate at 60fps. On Pro, there's dynamic resolution scaling that ranges from 1080p-4K native before being upscaled to 4K PSSR. With 1080p being the lowest internal resolution value, PSSR is still able to reconstruct an excellent 4K image in the most demanding areas.

name: Call Of Duty: Black Ops 6

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a mostly locked 60fps, or typically around 70-90fps with VRR. Improved global illumination (biggest improvement), ambient occlusion, reflections and 2-4x shadow resolution compared to performance mode.

modes.name: 120 hz refresh rate
modes.description: 1440p to 4K TAA at relatively stable 120fps. Graphics settings the same as base PS5 fidelity mode that runs at 60fps.

extraInfo: The anti-lag VRR implementation in fidelity mode (120hz refresh rate toggle off) means it actually has lower input latency than the 120hz mode, despite fewer frames. An improved PSSR implementation also arrived in a patch that significantly reduced artifacting/white dots in some areas, although they're still somewhat visible on rare occasions. Splitscreen multiplayer is now a locked 60fps (mid 50s on base PS5).

name: Chess Infinity
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen lighting, reflections and shadows

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1440p-4K native DRS at 30fps with all RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K TSR at 60fps with all RT.

extraInfo: Pro uses superior hardware-based RT compared to software-based RT on base PS5 (less breakup/clearer reflections etc). Performance can vary depending on scene complexity, which will then kick in the dynamic resolution scaling.

name: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen software-based global illumination/reflections and Nanite virtual shadow maps with RT

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-1552p DRS to 4K TSR at a locked 30fps. Both software-based Lumen GI and reflections, as well as RT shadows via Nanite (though not all shadows receive RT for accurate diffuse).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1062p-1386p DRS to 1800p TSR at a nearly locked 60fps. Lower quality Lumen GI/reflections compared to quality mode and no RT shadows.

extraInfo: Quality mode has a noticeably sharper image with less shimmer/breakup in hair. Performance mode can dip below 60fps, but stays well within the VRR window and only lasts a couple seconds. Base PS5 also has DRS and its internal resolution can go as low as 720p (performance) and 900p (quality), leading to far more shimmer/breakup. Real-time cutscenes are an uneven 30fps regardless of mode or hardware (even PC) and FMV cutscenes have visible macroblocking. The game boots in HDR but doesn't actually support it. Ensure HDR is toggled off for a superior SDR (in this case) image.

name: CyubeVR
resolution: 8K textures with dynamic foveated rendering for the rest of the image
extraInfo: Pro has increased distance for maximum LOD quality of the landscape and anything the player has built on it. Pro also has higher LOD quality for trees so changes are less noticeable from a distance.

name: Days Gone Remastered

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 2880p (5K) at a locked 30fps or around 35fps with VRR. Supersamples down to 4K (2160p) on 4K displays for the sharpest image of any mode on any console.

modes.name: enhanced
modes.description: 1584p to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps or around 70fps with VRR. As sharp as the native PS4 app playing on PS5 with no checkerboard rendering artifacts.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a 40fps, or around 55fps with VRR. PSSR used for aliasing, not upscaling. Sharper than enhanced mode but less sharp than quality mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1800p to 4K at a nearly locked 60fps, or around 65fps with VRR. Slightly blurrier than PS4 app on PS5, but has higher detailed LODs/no CBR artifacts.

extraInfo: Compared to PS4, the biggest upgrade is increased realism from new sky simulation, which renders accurate sunlight and darker nights. There's also increased foliage/draw distance (past PC max settings), as well as higher resolution shadows/textures, improved SSR/SSGI and more vibrant general lighting (sub-surface scattering/key lights). PSSR in enhanced mode is noisier in distant assets and foliage can blur when swaying, but looks much better in motion. VRR can be used in all modes, with Pro's balanced mode getting the most significant advantage over base PS5 when on. Base PS5 performance mode is much blurrier than the PS4 app on PS5.

name: Dead Island 2
extraInfo: Pro has improved shadow quality, motion blur, texture filtering and depth of field compared to base PS5. There's also longer draw distances and contact shadows on all objects/lights. The framerate is a locked 60fps like base PS5. Pro has DRS, but the resolution is above 2000p for the majority of gameplay, including often at native 4K. It can drop down as low as 1620p (technically lower than base PS5's fixed 1728p), but this is very rare only last a couple of seconds.

name: Dead Rising Deluxe
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections
extraInfo: Base PS5 doesn't have any RT implementation. Reflections are a big improvement with RT due to the shopping mall setting (storefront windows etc). You can toggle RT off, but Pro has a locked 60fps regardless. Whereas base PS5 dips into the low 50s in the most demanding scenarios. Both base PS5 and Pro run at a native 4K however.

name: Demon's Souls

modes.name: PS5 pro
modes.description: 1440p-1584p DRS to 4K PSSR with improved shadows at a locked 60fps.

modes.name: cinematic
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 4K native at locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 1440p at locked 60fps.

extraInfo: While the native 4K in base PS5's cinematic (quality) mode is a little sharper than the Pro mode, it's also far more noisy, more aliased, and less temporally stable than the 1440p-1584p DRS to 4K PSSR in the Pro mode, which therefore has the better image quality despite the lower base resolution. The Pro mode also has improved shadows and a locked 60fps.

name: Diablo IV
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and shadows

modes.name: enhanced visuals
modes.description: DRS that reaches up to 4K native at 30fps. RT shadows and reflections. Improves quality of fur, hair and fog compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 60fps. No RT.

extraInfo: Enhanced visuals mode hovers around 45-50fps with VRR, so VRR isn't recommended as that's below the 48fps VRR threshold on PlayStation. Pro's enhanced visuals mode also has higher resolutions, improved ambient occlusion and higher quality RT reflections compared to the same mode on base PS5.

name: Doom: The Dark Ages
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination
extraInfo: Pro drops frames in more demanding open arenas, but stays within the VRR window (mid 50s) and is still generally more stable than base PS5. Base PS5 renders between 1008p-1440p DRS (usually around 1080p) compared to the 1260p-1800p DRS (usually around 1620p) on Pro. With Pro's lower bounds only being in these more demanding/open arenas. RTGI quality is the same on both, but Pro has a slightly better draw distance and anisotropic filtering. Variable rate shading is used on every console (Xbox too), resulting in a blurrier image than the resolution would suggest. VRS is therefore least noticeable on Pro. Finally, RT reflections are PC only.

name: Dragon Age: The Veilguard
rtTypes: Ray traced ambient occlusion

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Roughly 1296p to 4K PSSR at nearly locked 30fps with RTAO.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Roughly 864p-1296p DRS to 1800p PSSR at nearly locked 60fps with RTAO. Can flicker a lot/look very aliased due to low base resolution.

extraInfo: Base PS5 uses FSR instead of PSSR, where it's 1080p to 1800p FSR (fidelity) and 864p to 1440p FSR (performance). Base PS5 is a lot softer, but less flickering/aliasing can make foliage/reflections look better compared to Pro. You can see the differences in the background of the menu when toggling between the modes (AO on foliage etc).

name: Dragon's Dogma 2
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at an unevenly paced 30fps. Around 40-50fps with VRR.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1080p to 4K PSSR at relatively locked 60fps (lows of low 50s).

modes.name: prioritize performance
modes.description: 720p to 4K PSSR at mostly locked 60fps. Usually around 70-85fps with VRR.

extraInfo: All modes can toggle RTGI on/off and the framerate is around 10 fewer with it activated. Due to PSSR, RT is noisy/aliased and looks worse as the base resolution lowers in subsequent modes. This exacerbation is also true with regular occlusion, although PSSR creates a sharper image and significantly improves ghosting, texture detail and material quality. Pro also hits its target framerate much more often than base PS5.

name: Dying Light 2: Stay Human
rtTypes: Ray traced shadows, reflections and ambient occlusion

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: Native 4K at 30 FPS. Better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 30 FPS with RT. Now with increased base resolution (1440p) and better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 60 FPS. Increased base resolution (1512p) compared to base PS5.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K with VRR, up to 120 FPS. Increased base resolution (1440p), better contact shadows, spot shadows, and fog quality compared to base PS5.

extraInfo: All modes also have improved Global Illumination, Screen Space Reflections (except quality mode due to RT) and Sub Surface Scattering compared to their equivalent base PS5 mode.

name: Dying Light: The Beast
rtTypes: Ray traced shadows, reflections and ambient occlusion

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: Native 4K at 30 FPS. Better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 30 FPS with RT. Now with increased base resolution (1440p) and better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 60 FPS. Increased base resolution (1512p) compared to base PS5.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K with VRR, up to 120 FPS. Increased base resolution (1440p), better contact shadows, spot shadows, and fog quality compared to base PS5.

extraInfo: No hard technical figures just yet, but Techland have publicly come out and said DL: The Beast will take it much further than DL2: SH. So we should expect what's above at the very least depending on the mode.

name: Dynasty Warriors: Origins

modes.name: native 4K
modes.description: 4K at a very unstable 60fps.

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1512p-4K DRS at a nearly locked 60fps.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1440p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Prioritize graphics mode's DRS averages around 1700p during actual gameplay and the framerate can dip into high 50s. Native 4K mode barely hits 60fps and is usually around 50fps during combat.

name: EA College Football 25
rtTypes: GIBS (EA's own global illumination - hardware ray tracing for indirect lighting)
extraInfo: Removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes seen in base PS5 for just one Pro mode. PSSR renders a sharper screen than even base PS5 resolution mode, but it causes certain assets like crowd handrails to be more unstable. All cutscenes are now also 60fps like in base PS5 performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps. Finally, the GIBS RT implementation seems unchanged.

name: EA College Football 26
rtTypes: GIBS (EA's own global illumination - hardware ray tracing for indirect lighting)
extraInfo: *College Football 26 isn't out yet, but the following College Football 25 information from last year should give us at least a good baseline of what to expect - 'Removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes seen in base PS5 for just one Pro mode. PSSR renders a sharper screen than even base PS5 resolution mode, but it causes certain assets like crowd handrails to be more unstable. All cutscenes are now also 60fps like in base PS5 performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps. Finally, the GIBS RT implementation seems unchanged.'

name: EA Sports FC 25
rtTypes: Ray traced ambient occlusion
extraInfo: Combines the resolution and enhanced visuals modes seen in base PS5 for just one Pro mode. Pro sometimes renders an even sharper image than base PS5 resolution mode, but still has the enhanced visuals mode RTAO on pitch lighting/kits etc. Cutscenes are now also 60fps, as opposed to 30fps on base PS5.

name: EA Sports UFC 5
extraInfo: Pro's resolution during gameplay is slightly higher than base PS5. Pro also renders KO replays at 60fps instead base PS5's 30fps. Other cutscenes like ring entrances remain at 30fps.

name: Empire Of The Ants
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen
extraInfo: Base PS5 has dynamic resolution scaling, which can have a higher internal resolution than Pro as it ranges from 1400p-1600p to 4K TSR, but it only runs at 30fps compared to Pro's locked 60fps. Pro's internal resolution of 1440p is also high enough that there is barely a difference between consoles once UE5's TSR is implemented.

name: Enlisted

modes.name: high quality
modes.description: 4K at a basically locked 60fps.

modes.name: high performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at a stable 120fps.

extraInfo: High performance mode now hits a solid 120fps whereas the base PS5 version is usually around 90fps. There's also higher quality shadows, improved Global Illumination and due to PSSR, the overall image quality has improved.

name: F1 24
rtTypes: Ray traced dynamic diffuse global illumination, ambient occlusion, shadows and reflections

modes.name: 8K
modes.description: 4K to 8K TAAU at a locked 30fps. Gameplay has all RT, including shadows. Requires an 8K TV as it can't be down-sampled.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR. Locked 60fps with all RT in gameplay except shadows.

modes.name: 120 Hz performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K TAAU. Mostly at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: Base PS5 quality mode has no RT during gameplay, whereas Pro has 3/4 RT which dramatically improves image realism. Pro even brings back shadows for cutscenes (which are now at 40fps, instead of 30fps) and replays. Base PS5 quality mode resolution is 1800p-4K DRS, yet PSSR very nearly matches its sharpness despite being at 1080p-1440p DRS. Base 120 Hz performance mode is also usually at 1080p compared to Pro's 1440p.

name: F1 25
rtTypes: Ray traced dynamic diffuse global illumination, ambient occlusion, shadows and reflections

modes.name: 8K
modes.description: 4K to 8K TAAU at a locked 30fps. Gameplay has all RT, including shadows. Requires an 8K TV as it can't be down-sampled.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR. Locked 60fps with all RT in gameplay except shadows.

modes.name: 120 Hz performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K TAAU. Mostly at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: *F1 25 hasn't had a tech deep dive yet, but the following F1 24 information from last year should give us at least a good baseline of what to expect - 'Base PS5 quality mode has no RT during gameplay, whereas Pro has 3/4 RT which dramatically improves image realism. Pro even brings back shadows for cutscenes (which are now at 40fps, instead of 30fps) and replays. Base PS5 quality mode resolution is 1800p-4K DRS, yet PSSR very nearly matches its sharpness despite being at 1080p-1440p DRS. Base 120 Hz performance mode is also usually at 1080p compared to Pro's 1440p.'

name: Faaast Penguin
extraInfo: The only display setting in the options menu is a brightness slider. However, Pro has a locked framerate and runs within an 120hz container to improve input lag (base PS5 still at 60hz). Pro could potentially sometimes render below 4K native, but these dips would be so minor that the game still has a 4K-like image.

name: Farming Simulator 25
extraInfo: Whereas base PS5 has a quality (1600p to 4K at 30fps) and performance 60fps mode, Pro just has a singular mode that runs at a native 4K at a basically locked 60fps.

name: Final Fantasy VII Rebirth

modes.name: versatility
modes.description: 1224p-1440 DRS to 4K PSSR at a very stable 60fps.

modes.name: graphics
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 1880p-4K native DRS at locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 performance mode(s), with a sharp or smooth variation. 1152p-1440p DRS at a stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Pro's new versatility mode runs at 1224p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a very stable 60fps. All base PS5 modes are present and its 30fps graphics mode can have a higher internal resolution. However the PSSR implementation, though a bit noisier/unstable, still creates a far sharper image (especially distant detail), with better SSR and less ghosting/artifacting, at 60fps. Considering versatility mode has both the clearest resolution and highest/most stable framerate (its 60fps is more stable than the performance mode), all other modes are redundant.

name: Fortnite
rtTypes: Hardware-based ray traced reflections, shadows and global illumination

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1350p to 4K TSR at a near locked 60fps with hardware-based RT reflections, shadows & global illumination.

modes.name: 120fps performance
modes.description: 1080p to 4K TSR at a basically locked 120fps, but with no RT.

extraInfo: Pro's performance mode looks practically identical to base PS5's performance mode. Base PS5's fidelity mode only uses software-based RT, meaning Pro has better RT implementation due to being hardware-based (less breakup/shimmering/pop-in, more detailed/stable assets, character models in reflections, more accurate indirect lighting).

name: Forza Horizon 5
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps. RT reflections on player car in races and free roam gameplay.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at a locked 60fps. Same graphical settings as quality mode, but with no RT reflections.

extraInfo: Graphics in Pro's performance mode are equivalent to base PS5's quality mode, but at a locked 60fps instead of 30fps. Base PS5's performance mode is a big step down from all others. It has far less foliage onscreen, more pop-in, and can render under 4K (DRS hovers around 1728p-1872p when it drops) for a few seconds. RT on Pro is nice, but only affects certain assets (only player car, not other racers etc) and is hard to notice in general gameplay. Cutscenes are 30fps regardless of mode or console.

name: Gears Of War: Reloaded
extraInfo: Xbox has confirmed that even base consoles will have 4K, 120fps in MP and VRR support. It's therefore safe to assume for now, at the very least, Pro will have a higher framerate when running at 4K in MP. Reloaded also improves visual settings over the 2015 Xbox One Ultimate Edition like shadows/reflections etc. RT is even on the table for Pro and maybe even base PS5 given its inclusion in Gears 5. Again, this is all speculative though and we won't 100% know until its August release.

name: Ghost Of Y≈çtei
extraInfo: *The following technical information is based off Digital Foundry's analysis of various Ghost Of Y≈çtei and Tsushima trailers. It's therefore all subject to change, but gives us a good baseline of what to expect - 'Facial animations of main characters look vastly improved over GoT, with more subtlety and detail. GoY is running at 4K/30fps in trailers, but there's no form of RT. It therefore looks worse when compared to similar games such as AC: Shadows. Shadow resolution does however seems to be much higher compared to GoT. There's no official confirmation of a performance mode or VRR to push past 60fps, but it's likely given Sucker Punch's past work on PS5.'

name: God Of War: Ragnar√∂k
rtTypes: Very light ray traced reflections for scene-aligned cube maps

modes.name: PS5 pro enhanced
modes.description: Quality settings of base PS5 (RT, better shadows/ambient occlusion/textures & longer draw distance than HFR) but runs at 4K/60+fps instead of 30fps.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: Unlocks framerate for up to 120fps (often around 70-105fps depending on upscaler) on VRR displays.

modes.name: Favor Quality
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 quality mode capped at 30fps. Now redundant.

modes.name: Favor Performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 performance mode capped at 60fps. Now redundant.

extraInfo: Pro can toggle between TAA and PSSR for upscaling. PSSR is sharper and clearer (especially distant assets) with less fizzle in motion, but less stable with around 10-20 frames fewer. Both upscalers use 1440p as the base resolution. No need to bother with the legacy base PS5 modes as there are no advantages to do so.

name: Gran Turismo 7
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections

modes.name: 8K 60hz
modes.description: 4K to 8K PSSR at a locked 60fps, but with no RT. Requires PSSR to upscale.

modes.name: prioritize ray-tracing/resolution
modes.description: 4K PSSR/TAA at a locked 60fps with RT reflections.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1800p to 4K PSSR/TAA at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: Unlike base PS5, RT reflections are now available during gameplay. Its excellent implementation is far superior to the cube maps used when RT is disabled. Both TAA and PSSR are available for upscaling. RT is available with both except for cockpit mode, which is only PSSR. PSSR still looks great, but can can produce additional shimmer/noise in thin objects and artifacting on a few cars compared to TAA. All framerates are locked 99% of the time in gameplay, but replays can drop the framerate more often. Finally, Pro significantly improves motion clarity and image quality inside PSVR2.

name: Grand Theft Auto 6
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination and reflections
extraInfo: *GTA 6 isn't confirmed to be Pro enhanced yet, but considering its budget, IP legacy, how Rockstar Games are perfectionists, and it's currently the most anticipated game, it's the one game worth fully speculating. All info is from DF's analysis of the second trailer which was real-time on base PS5, making it a good baseline of what to expect on Pro. GTA 6 rendered at 1440p including letter-boxing, which won't make it into the game. There's diffuse RTGI for direct/indirect lighting and it's more stable compared to software UE5 Lumen that's popular on consoles. There's RT reflections that includes dynamic objects like people, even on rough/opaque surfaces (water etc), but SSR is still sometimes used in combination. RT reflections on transparent surfaces (glass) is top-tier. There's no RT shadows, but still looks great with accurate diffuse. The trailer's most impressive aspect is the accurate/natural hair rendering, regardless of hairstyle and even body hair. A 60fps mode is unlikely, but 40fps could be possible.

name: Helldivers 2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at an improperly paced, but stable 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p at a mostly stable 60fps (drops to 50s with explosions etc).

extraInfo: Pro sees resolution increases in both modes as on base PS5, quality mode is 1728p and performance is 1080p. However, both consoles render a relatively unstable image due to mediocre TAA, regardless of mode. There's therefore a larger gap between performance modes, with less shimmering/clearer text on Pro. Pro's 60fps is more stable than base PS5, with only the hardest difficulties causing 5-10fps drops (still within VRR). Both quality modes are improperly paced, but Pro is more stable.

name: Hitman Trilogy
extraInfo: Pro is a locked 60fps at 4K native, compared to the 1800p mostly stable 60fps on base PS5. Essentially, putting Pro on par with the Series X version.

name: Hogwarts Legacy
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and shadows

modes.name: fidelity ray-tracing
modes.description: 1728p to 4K PSSR at nearly locked 30fps with RT reflections and shadows.

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1728p to 4K PSSR at locked 30fps without RT.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Only for 120hz screens. 4K PSSR at nearly locked 40fps without RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at nearly locked 60fps without RT.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: Only for 120hz/VRR screens. Can drop to 1080p as base resolution and no framerate cap. Usually around 80fps.

extraInfo: You can remove the framerate cap in the fidelity and balanced modes, increasing the framerate by 5-10. RT shadows are better quality than base PS5, but less accurate on some moving objects. RT reflections have twice the resolution on Pro compared to base PS5. It also applies to bodies of water unlike base PS5 which uses SSR, though can look noisy due to PSSR. Pro performance modes have same graphical settings as the other Pro modes outside of RT. Base PS5 uses FSR 1 to upscale, which looks sharper, but more aliased than PSSR.

name: Horizon 1 Zero Dawn

modes.name: favor resolution pro
modes.description: 1584p-4K native DRS at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced pro
modes.description: Looks almost identical to favor performance pro mode, but is capped at 40fps.

modes.name: favor performance pro
modes.description: 1440p-1584p DRS to 4K at a locked 60fps, or around 65fps with VRR. Very slightly more blurry than favor resolution pro mode (particularly SSR) due to lower base resolution before upscaling, but looks less aliased in motion.

extraInfo: All 3 modes have improved shadows, depth-of-field, skin/hair shaders, clouds, god rays etc compared to base PS5, and these improvements are even more noticeable in motion. Base PS5 also has DRS that hits max 1800p checkerboarding in performance mode, which looks far blurrier (especially foliage and SSR in bodies of water) and more aliased/unstable than Pro performance mode. Pro performance mode even beats base PS5 resolution mode except for slightly blurrier SSR. Digital Foundry thinks it's the best looking console game (along with Horizon Forbidden West) ever! Equivalent to a high-end PC game and even beats DLSS in places like SSR.

name: Horizon 2 Forbidden West

modes.name: favor resolution pro
modes.description: 1584p-4K native DRS at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced pro
modes.description: Looks almost identical to favor performance pro mode, but is capped at 40fps.

modes.name: favor performance pro
modes.description: 1440p-1584p DRS to 4K at a locked 60fps, or around 65fps with VRR. Very slightly more blurry than favor resolution pro mode (particularly SSR) due to lower base resolution before upscaling, but looks less aliased in motion.

extraInfo: All 3 modes have improved shadows, depth-of-field, skin/hair shaders, clouds, god rays etc compared to base PS5, and these improvements are even more noticeable in motion. Base PS5 also has DRS that hits max 1800p checkerboarding in performance mode, which looks far blurrier (especially foliage and SSR in bodies of water) and more aliased/unstable than Pro performance mode. Pro performance mode even beats base PS5 resolution mode except for slightly blurrier SSR. Digital Foundry thinks it's the best looking console game (along with Horizon Zero Dawn) ever! Equivalent to a high-end PC game and even beats DLSS in places like SSR.

name: Hunt: Showdown 1896
extraInfo: According to Crytek, Pro has 'increased graphical settings' compared to base PS5 and Pro's 60fps is more stable. PSSR also creates a sharper image than the 1260p to 4K FSR2 on base PS5. However, Pro's PSSR implementation results in a lot more shimmering/flickering than FSR2. To the point that many feel Pro's image looks worse despite the sharper render. There's also anecdotal comments throughout the community that Pro crashes more often.

name: Indiana Jones: GC
pageTitle: Indiana Jones And The Great Circle
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination
extraInfo: Pro's dynamic resolution scale ranges from 1440p to native 4K, which it regularly hits. Base PS5's DRS only renders up to 1800p and dips as low as 1200p. Both consoles have a very stable 60fps framerate, but Pro hits 60fps slightly more often. Even with its slightly improved RTGI and ambient occlusion/shadows implementation. There's no option to unlock the framerate, even though Pro looks like it has the headroom for a noticeable increase past 60fps. Cutscenes are locked to 60fps everywhere (even PC).

name: Karma: The Dark World
extraInfo: The developers claim Pro is native 4K, but also using PSSR in order to get a 'rock solid' 60fps. Pro also has enhanced texture streaming and volumetric effects, higher quality texture filtering, improved distance rendering, and better temporal stability compared to base PS5.

name: Kayak VR: Mirage
extraInfo: Pro has 8K textures compared to 4K on base PS5. Pro also has improved post-processing, effects, LOD distance and anti-aliasing. Both consoles have dynamic resolution scaling, but Pro only hits a low of 90% of 4K, whereas base PS5 can only render between 60%-90% of 4K.

name: Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2
extraInfo: Pro is 1296p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps, or around 70fps (highs of 90s) with VRR on. Base PS5 is only 1080p to 1440p FSR at 60fps, though 1440p to 4K FSR at 30fps. Even though Pro can have a lower base resolution before upscaling, PSSR still produces the clearest (albeit a little noisier) image. Pro also has the same improved tree/shadow LODs, ambient occlusion and object quality of base PS5's fidelity mode, but at 60fps, making Pro's mode the best of both worlds.

name: Lies Of P

modes.name: quality-centered
modes.description: 4K at 40fps+ depending on if HFR (VRR) is activated. Higher quality shadows, textures, SSR and volumetric fog than performance-centered mode.

modes.name: performance-centered
modes.description: 4K at a basically locked 60fps. HFR is disabled in this mode.

extraInfo: Pro performance-centered mode is a native 4K, whereas base PS5 performance-centered mode has DRS that internally renders between 1512p-1800p, before upscaling to 4K. Pro quality-centered mode also has a 30% increase in FPS compared to base PS5 quality-centered mode's 30fps.

name: Like A Dragon: Pirate Yakuza In Hawaii
pageTitle: Like A Dragon: Pirate Yakuza In Hawaii
extraInfo: While both Pro and base PS5 run at 60fps, Pro's framerate is basically locked at 60fps whereas base PS5 can dip below more often. Base PS5's lower 1080p internal resolution (compared to Pro's 1440p) also results in noticeably more fizzle in assets like hair.

name: Lords Of The Fallen
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps with Lumen GI.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K via a custom version of UE5's upscaling at 60fps plus Lumen.

extraInfo: Hexworks states that Pro has a 40% increase in pixels compared to base PS5, resulting in sharper distant details and more refined textures on characters/environments. In practice, this increase can be even larger as base PS5 performance mode is between 648p-1152p DRS and quality mode is 1296p-1620p DRS. Pro also hits its target framerate more often than base PS5 in both modes and is equivalent to the highest PC graphical settings.

name: Lost Soul Aside
rtTypes: Ray traced lighting, shadows and reflections (likely)
extraInfo: LSA ships in August, but based off Yang Bing's (LSA creator) comments, we can make educated assumptions on a few things. Firstly, Bing has stated that Pro will run at a higher resolution and more stable framerate than base PS5. Bing is also receiving significant aid from Sony's China Hero Project, who convinced him to stick with the less resource-intensive Unreal Engine 4. The PlayStation official page also hints to RT lighting, shadows and reflections, with PC specs already confirming its happening there. All this suggests there's a good chance Pro will be able to come close to the visual triangle of 4K, 60fps and RT. Perhaps using PSSR (unconfirmed) to achieve this.

name: Madden NFL 25
extraInfo: Removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes seen in base PS5 for just one Pro mode. PSSR renders a sharper screen than even base PS5 resolution mode (especially grass), but it causes certain assets like crowd handrails to be more noisy/unstable. All cutscenes are now also 60fps like in base PS5 performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps.

name: Madden NFL 26
extraInfo: *Madden 26 isn't out yet, but the following Madden 25 information from last year should give us at least a good baseline of what to expect. Especially as this is the first current-gen Madden to not release on PS4 - 'Removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes seen in base PS5 for just one Pro mode. PSSR renders a sharper screen than even base PS5 resolution mode (especially grass), but it causes certain assets like crowd handrails to be more noisy/unstable. All cutscenes are now also 60fps like in base PS5 performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps.'

name: Mandragora: WOTWT
pageTitle: Mandragora: Whispers of the Witch Tree

modes.name: quality pro
modes.description: 4K native at a stable 60fps.

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p native that targets 120fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 only has one mode that runs at 1800p/60fps. While this is just slightly worse than Pro's 4K/60fps quality mode, it means that Pro has an exclusive 120fps mode for gamers who prefer to maximize the framerate.

name: Marathon
extraInfo: So far, the only technical information Bungie has disclosed is that Marathon will utilize PSSR on Pro. However, both 120fps and/or a 4K final render are likely. These educated assumptions are based off Marathon's focus on art style over resource-intensive realism, as well as their previous game (Destiny 2) already achieving these metrics on a base PS5, as the game isn't Pro enhanced.

name: Marvel Rivals
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen global illumination and reflections

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, with Lumen Reflections & GI.

modes.name: HFR
modes.description: 1440p at a nearly locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 only has Lumen GI in its quality mode, whereas Pro also has Lumen Reflections. Pro's PSSR implementation renders a sharper image than possible on base PS5, but is also a bit noisier/unstable. Pro also not only hits 120fps in its HFR mode much more often than base PS5, which regularly dips to around 110fps, but does so at a higher resolution too.

name: Metal Gear Solid Delta: SE
extraInfo: Konami has confirmed that there will be both a quality and performance mode on Pro. They've also confirmed that Pro will use PSSR, but didn't mention if it's just for performance mode or for both. RT is currently labelled as false, but based off the PC requirements (minimum specs require at least a 2060 Super GPU), it's very possible that Pro could utilize RT, at least in quality mode. Likely Unreal Engine 5's Lumen and hopefully the superior hardware-based version, but this is all speculation.

name: Midnight Murder Club
extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5 run at 4K. Instead, Pro surpasses the base PS5 version by its ability to maintain a locked 60fps, regardless of what VFX Quality setting is chosen. There is very low, low, medium, high and best, and it's at these higher options where base PS5 can dip below 60fps. Especially if the FOV is also on a wider setting. Pro will however remain a locked 60fps even if both are maxed out.

name: Monster Hunter Wilds
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections

modes.name: prioritize resolution
modes.description: 1728p-1944p DRS to 4K PSSR with RT reflections. Nearly locked 30fps, or up to 45fps with VRR.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1404p to 4K PSSR with very slightly worse RT than prioritize resolution mode. Nearly locked 40fps, or low 40s in VRR.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1080p to 4K PSSR with RT disabled. Nearly locked 60fps, or up to 80fps with VRR. Worse GI, lighting and LODs than other modes.

extraInfo: RT reflections look significantly better than SSR due to no occlusion issues. Pro's PSSR looks much better than base PS5's FSR1 as the image (though slightly softer) has a lot less aliasing/breakup and more temporal stability. This contrast is widened as internal resolution lowers to as low as 720p on base PS5. Pro prioritize framerate mode also hits 60fps more often than the base PS5 version. There's no LFC, so VRR isn't recommended in resolution/balanced modes that rarely reach above 60fps anyways.

name: Mortal Kombat 1
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections
extraInfo: The only big difference between Pro and base PS5 is how reflections are rendered. Pro uses RT, whereas base PS5 uses less accurate SSR (screen space reflections). Pro still has dynamic resolution scaling that can go as low as 1800p, but renders at native 4K more often than base PS5.

name: My First Gran Turismo
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections

modes.name: 8K 60hz
modes.description: 4K to 8K PSSR at locked 60fps, but with no RT. Requires PSSR to upscale.

modes.name: prioritize ray-tracing/resolution
modes.description: 4K PSSR/TAA at locked 60fps with RT reflections.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1800p to 4K PSSR/TAA at locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: *MFTG is a f2p beginner-friendly introduction to the world of GT. Basically, an expanded demo with a limited number of cars/racetracks. However, its tech details remain the same as the premium GT7 product - 'Unlike base PS5, RT reflections are now available during gameplay. Its excellent implementation is far superior to the cube maps used when RT is disabled. Both TAA and PSSR are available for upscaling. RT is available with both except for cockpit mode, which is only PSSR. PSSR still looks great, but can can produce additional shimmer/noise in thin objects and artifacting on a few cars compared to TAA. All framerates are locked 99% of the time in gameplay, but replays can drop the framerate more often. Finally, Pro significantly improves motion clarity and image quality inside PSVR2.'

name: Naraka: Bladepoint

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at 60fps. According to 24 Entertainment - 'ideal for users seeking better visual experiences'.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1080p (likely) to 4K PSSR, with either a 60fps or 120fps cap - 'balancing both visual quality and smoothness'.

modes.name: high frames
modes.description: Native 1080p at 60fps, 120fps, 240fps, or 'unlimited' fps (check extra info) - 'for users who need the highest frame rates, ensuring smoother gameplay'.

extraInfo: 60fps at native 4K isn't possible on base PS5. Although high frames mode has toggles for 240fps and unlimited fps, Pro isn't capable of running above 120fps. So in practice, high frames mode has the same 60/120fps cap toggles as balanced mode. It'll just maintain the target framerate more often due to the lower resolution.

name: NBA 2K25
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections
extraInfo: The biggest difference between Pro and base PS5 is the addition of RT reflections in The City. Pro also uses PSSR to upscale from 1440p (likely) to 4K. This creates a slightly sharper image compared to base PS5, however PSSR also causes certain assets like handrails in the stands to render a bit more unstable.

name: Ninja Gaiden 2 Black
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen reflections and global illumination

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Upscaled 4K TSR at locked 60fps except for some cutscenes (lows of mid 50s).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 1080p TSR at somewhat stable 120fps depending on level (lows of 90s). Less detailed shadows/non-Nanite geometry.

extraInfo: There's no actual modes. Instead, you switch between the 2 via the FPS limit toggle that has 60 and 120 values. Both modes use Lumen combined with SSR for reflections and Lumen GI for indirect lighting. Base PS5 has the same 2 modes, however, Pro has a higher base resolution before upscaling and hits its target framerate more often.

name: No Man's Sky

modes.name: 8K resolution
modes.description: 2592-2700p DRS to 8K PSSR at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a basically locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Both modes also have improved lighting, ultra quality reflections and higher quality ambient occlusion compared to base PS5. These improvements are also seen in the PSVR2 version. PSSR implementation works very well due to the high base resolution.

name: Off The Grid

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K FSR3/TSR/PSSR at usually around 65fps with VRR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p FSR3/TSR/PSSR at usually around 85fps with VRR.

extraInfo: Pro can choose between FSR3, TSR or PSSR for upscaling. All 3 run at a similar fps (give or take 5-10fps) and can be capped at 30/40/60fps. However, while FSR3 and TSR (a bit more stable) render a good image, PSSR results in shimmering/flickering, as well as strobing in assets like foliage. Similar to SW Jedi: Survivor when Pro launched, before getting patched. Fidelity mode renders quite a 4K-looking image and is 99% locked above the 48fps VRR window. Performance mode has a roughly 20fps increase and even hits 120fps sometimes, but the 1080p-like image is much blurrier regardless of upscaler.

name: Oppidum
extraInfo: Pro is a native 4K at 60fps. This combines the best of base PS5's performance (1440p/60fps) and quality (4K/30fps) modes.

name: Outbreak: SOHCS
pageTitle: Outbreak: Shades of Horror Chromatic Split
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and shadows
extraInfo: Uses PSSR to hit 4K (base resolution unknown, but almost certainly above 1080p due to final output). Pro also has significantly enhanced RT, texture resolution, other visual effects etc compared to base PS5, and hits 60fps more often.

name: Paladin's Passage

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K PSSR at 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at 60fps.

extraInfo: According to the game's website, 'advanced shaders' are now on Pro. PSSR is also used to render up to 8K.

name: Path Of Exile 2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1662p NIS or PSSR 'quality' to 4K with DRS, at a locked 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p NIS or PSSR 'balanced' to 4K without DRS, at a relatively stable 120fps.

extraInfo: With 4 upscalers that each have multiple quality options within them, a sharpness slider, different lighting toggles, multiple refresh rate options (including 30/40fps), and even experimental options like dynamic culling, PoE2 easily has the most configurations of a PS5 Pro game. Instead of listing 50+ modes, the 2 above represent what the general PoE2 community recommend depending on your framerate target. Performance mode can dip in heavy fights, but should stay above 60fps most of the time. NIS is sharper and more performant that PSSR, but less stable in motion and can look too sharp. Though PSSR's softness results in a loss of texture detail. If you want to maximize frames, ensure lighting is set to just 'shadows' instead of  'shadows + GI'. Dynamic culling is also not recommended as it can cause severe graphical issues.

name: Pathfinder: WOTR

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a mostly stable 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Quality mode can dip below 60fps, but it's not common. Even when it happens, it's around the low 50's which is well within the VRR window. Performance mode is a locked 60fps, but at 1/4 of the resolution so looks noticeably blurrier. Base PS5 only has one mode which does render at 4K, but with a far more unstable 60fps framerate that regularly falls below the VRR window.

name: Pure Pool Pro
rtTypes: TBD

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K at 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at 120fps.

extraInfo: Ripstone's Reddit account confirmed that the above modes is what Pro will be targeting. We'll see if this holds true when the games releases in the announced end of Q3/start of Q4 2025 window.

name: Ratchet & Clank: Rift Apart
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and ambient occlusion

modes.name: fidelity pro
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps/40fps for 60hz/120hz screens, or nearly 60fps with VRR. Highest quality RT (explained below).

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1584p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or around 80-90fps with VRR.

extraInfo: Fidelity Pro is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, but PSSR in general resolves more detail than FSR  seen in every base PS5 mode. Especially in motion with less aliasing etc, but can be noisier in stills. Performance Pro mode has much sharper RT reflections than base PS5 Performance RT mode. Fidelity Pro RT reflections look even less aliased as they're full resolution and its RTAO has more contact shadows, adding depth to assets all over the screen.

name: Redacted

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K at a locked 60fps with supersampling.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at a locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 doesn't have an 8K mode. It also can't run at 120fps when rendering at 4K. You can choose Pro's quality mode on a non-8K screen, but the game makes it clear that the game will be down-sampled to the resolution of your screen and therefore make this choice pointless.

name: Resident Evil 4
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: Native 4K at a locked 60fps with RT/better hair quality. Can also toggle HFR on which then increases the framerate to 70-90fps.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR without RT/better hair quality. 85-105fps usually, but can be a locked 120fps in interiors.

extraInfo: There's a lot of toggles in this game for RT/HFR/better hair quality etc, so the 2 modes above represent the image quality with all the toggles either on or off. Resolution mode holds a much more stable 60fps than same mode on base PS5, which hovers around 45fps.

name: Resident Evil Village
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination, ambient occlusion and reflections

modes.name: ray tracing
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps with RT.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: You can actually toggle both RT and HFR on, with the framerate then ranging from from 65-90fps. 120fps is not on base PS5, which uses 4K checkerboard rendering (1920x2160) and can't hold a stable 60fps. PSSR is less sharp compared to base PS5's CBR, but also less noisy, with less artifacting on moving objects like tree branches.

name: Resist
extraInfo: There is only one difference between Pro and base PS5. Pro runs at 120hz whereas base PS5 runs at 90hz.

name: Retrieval
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections
extraInfo: The Pro version will have more detailed environments, higher quality RT reflections and a sharper resolution compared to the base PS5 version. All at a more stable 60fps.

name: Returnal
rtTypes: Ray traced audio
extraInfo: Pro has roughly 2.5x the resolution compared to base PS5, resulting in a very frequent internal resolution of 1728p max (infrequent DRS of 1350p min) that outputs to 4K (base PS5 is a fixed 1080p that reconstructs to 1440p before upscaling to a 4K checkerboard). This leads to a less noisy/grainy image with less aliasing/flickering, though some image instability remains. Both PS5 consoles have framerate dips into the low 50s, but this occurs less often on Pro. Technically, Returnal uses other forms of RT outside of audio. However, this is only for background calculations, not for visual improvements, so it's not listed.

name: Rise Of The Ronin
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections

modes.name: prioritize graphics + ray tracing
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR with RT reflections at a very unstable 60fps (usually around 45fps in actual gameplay).

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR. Slightly higher average framerate than prioritize graphics + RT mode.

modes.name: prioritize FPS
modes.description: 1070p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps with no RT.

extraInfo: Both graphics modes' framerate fall far below the VRR limit for a majority of gameplay. You can cap the framerate to 30fps, but it has uneven frame pacing so these modes will feel choppy regardless of your setup. The superior RT reflections make little difference in this scenario because of the framerate issue. Prioritize FPS mode however runs great, and even with the lower bound of its dynamic resolution scaling, Pro's PSSR renders a more clear/less aliased image than base PS5's FSR (even in its graphics modes). Especially with foliage which regularly fills the screen.

name: RoadCraft

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-4K native DRS to 4K FSR3 at 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K FSR3 at 60fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 also uses dynamic resolution scaling. However, its lowest internal resolution is 720p in base PS5 performance mode and it can only reach up to 1440p in its quality mode. Pro is therefore much sharper as its rendering 2x the pixels when both PS5 consoles max out their resolution, but this is the only difference between them.

name: Rogue Flight

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K at a very stable 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at a very stable 120fps.

extraInfo: According to Truant Pixel, outside of resolution/framerate increases compared to the same modes on base PS5, Pro also has 'additional small graphical touches'.

name: Shredders
extraInfo: Base PS5 and Pro both achieve a nearly locked 60fps. However, Pro runs at 4K native compared to base PS5's 1440p, which is a 2x resolution increase.

name: Silent Hill 2
rtTypes: Hardware-based ray traced reflections and global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p to 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps with hardware-based RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 900p-1152p DRS to 4K TSR. Somewhat stable 60fps (lows of high 40s) with hardware-based RT.

extraInfo: Pro uses superior hardware-based RT compared to software-based RT on base PS5 (less breakup/clearer reflections etc) and both modes hit target framerate more often than their base PS5 version. Pro's performance mode also has a higher base resolution. However, Pro's quality mode, despite a more 4K like image and better RT, has so much PSSR shimmer that base PS5 quality mode looks better with TSR. Bloober should improve the PSSR implementation or revert to TSR (as they did for performance).

name: Slitterhead
extraInfo: A native 4K and more stable 60fps compared to base PS5, especially in later boss fights. *Technical information is aggregated off anecdotal remarks by gamers who have completed Slitterhead, not from a primary source or established secondary source like Digital Foundry as none exist at time of writing.

name: Smash Drums

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 120fps with higher resolution and better VFX compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 120fps native.

extraInfo: Whereas base PS5 is only 90fps in its fidelity mode and 120fps performance mode, Pro is 120fps in both.

name: Sniper Elite: Resistance
extraInfo: Both PS5 consoles have dynamic resolution scaling, but Pro hits native 4K often, which is extremely rare on base PS5. Base PS5 also renders a low of 1296p often when that's less than 1% on Pro. However, all versions (Xbox/PC too) are poorly aliased, so resolution gaps are less noticeable than in other games because there's so much shimmer regardless. Pro's 60fps is locked aside from some effect-heavy explosions. This is more stable than base PS5, which can drop to low 50s in general gameplay.

name: Spider-Man 1 Remastered
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, shadows and ambient occlusion

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 fidelity mode (all RT/more asset density etc). 4K at locked 30fps/40fps for 60hz/120hz screens.

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or usually around 75-90fps with VRR. Fidelity mode level of image quality (RT/increased pedestrian density etc).

extraInfo: Performance Pro (which Insomniac recommends) now has RT unlike base PS5 performance mode. Fidelity mode is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, especially in areas like reflections, but its not at 60fps and PSSR still resolves more detail than seen on base PS5.

name: Spider-Man: Miles Morales
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, shadows and ambient occlusion

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 fidelity mode (all RT/more asset density etc). 4K at locked 30fps/40fps for 60hz/120hz screens.

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or usually around 75-90fps with VRR. Fidelity mode level of image quality (RT/increased pedestrian density etc).

extraInfo: Performance Pro (which Insomniac recommends) now has RT unlike base PS5 performance mode. Fidelity mode is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, especially in areas like reflections, but its not at 60fps and PSSR still resolves more detail than seen on base PS5.

name: Spider-Man 2
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, shadows (key light) and ambient occlusion

modes.name: fidelity pro
modes.description: 4K PSSR at locked 30fps/40fps for 60hz/120hz screens, or usually around mid 50s with VRR. Highest quality RT (explained below).

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or usually around 70fps with VRR. Base PS5's fidelity mode level of RT quality.

extraInfo: Fidelity Pro is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, but PSSR in Performance Pro still resolves more detail than the upscaler seen in any base PS5 mode. Fidelity Pro RT key light shadows now includes very distant buildings, RT reflections are full resolution (50% in Performance Pro) and RTAO has more contact shadows, adding depth to assets all over the screen. RT types can be toggled on/off which affects VRR framerate approx +- 10. Draw distance/distant reflections are also improved over Performance Pro (which is at base PS5 Fidelity mode), e.g. more onscreen distant objects like trees. Graphics settings are equivalent to PC's high/very high.

name: Split Fiction
extraInfo: The framerate is a locked 60fps. Base PS5 has DRS which internally renders at 1800p max (lows of around 1523p) compared to a fixed 4K native on Pro. However, due to the current aliasing implementation Pro (and PC) use, certain assets like railings can look more jagged despite the higher resolution. This is likely a bug that will be an easy fix in a future patch (not PSSR as SF doesn't use it). Despite being on Unreal Engine 5, the Pro (and again, even PC) doesn't use any form of RT including UE5's Lumen.

name: Star Wars Jedi: Survivor
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, global illumination and ambient occlusion

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1584p to 4K PSSR. Locked 30fps with more detailed RT implementation compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 900p average DRS to 1800p PSSR. Nearly locked at 60fps with RT.

extraInfo: Pro now has the latest PSSR version, which is far less noisy/unstable/shimmery than the original, objectively ugly patch. Flickering in foliage and RT reflections are especially improved and is now on par with FSR on base PS5. PSSR is also sharper than FSR (and even DLSS on PC) in motion, though softest in stills. Pro performance mode also brings back RT that's not in the base PS5 version, but the implementation is still worse than either PS5's quality mode.

name: Star Wars Outlaws
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 900p-1152p DRS at a nearly locked 60fps.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Sharper than quality pro (1512p-1800p DRS) but at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Visual quality downgraded compared to quality but now at a locked 40fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Lowest visual quality of all modes. Usually 936p DRS at a nearly locked 60fps compared to base PS5 at 720p DRS.

extraInfo: All modes can use either PSSR or FSR3 for upscaling. FSR looks clearer/less noisy with assets like foliage in stills, but the difference is miniscule now that Outlaws updated its PSSR implementation, which beats FSR in motion. Quality mode is the only one that provides stable RT. Quality/balanced/performance are all the legacy modes from base PS5, but will run at the higher DRS bounds (1800p for quality etc) more often due to the Pro's extra power.

name: Stellar Blade

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1800p to 4K PSSR. A very nearly locked 80fps on 120hz screens and 60fps on 60hz screens.

modes.name: pro max
modes.description: 4K TAA at 50-60fps.

modes.name: prioritize resolution
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 quality mode. See below for reasons why it's redundant.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 balanced mode. See below for reasons why it's redundant.

modes.name: prioritize performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 performance mode. See below for reasons why it's redundant.

extraInfo: The legacy modes from base PS5 are still present, but like Pro Max mode, they use TAA. The 80fps Pro mode is the only one that uses PSSR. The PSSR implementation is far better than TAA at de-noising/sharpening/stabilizing/de-shimmering the image. So even with a lower base resolution (1800p), Pro mode looks better than the native 4K TAA in Pro Max, let alone the legacy modes that max out at 60fps. With the best image quality and highest framerate, Pro mode makes all the others redundant.

name: Stunt Paradise
extraInfo: While both the base PS5 and Pro versions run at 120fps, base PS5 is limited to 1440p. Pro runs at 4K, which is 2x the resolution and with a nearly locked framerate.

name: Subside
extraInfo: Both base PS5 and Pro run at 90fps with no reprojection. However, Pro has dynamic shadows and an edge blur effect. Pro also has a 2.5x foveated resolution increase compared to the 2.25x increase on base PS5. Finally, the developers believe Pro's dynamic shadows is the most significant improvement.

name: Test Drive Unlimited: SC

modes.name: graphics
modes.description: 1440p to 4K TAA at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p at a nearly locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 graphics mode only renders at 1440p, but there is little difference in practice. Pro is also able to achieve its target framerate more often.

name: The Callisto Protocol
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and shadows

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 6K to 8K TAAU at locked 30fps with RT. Can be down-sampled back to 4K for a clearer image on 4K screens.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 4K TAAU at a very stable 40fps with RT. Higher internal resolution than performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1296p-1440p DRS to 4K TAAU at a nearly locked 60fps with RT.

extraInfo: Performance mode has the biggest jump from base PS5 as that performance mode has no RT and a more unstable 60fps. RT quality is the same on Pro and base PS5, so there isn't much difference in the quality modes outside of resolution.

name: The Crew Motorfest
extraInfo: Looks much more detailed than even base PS5's 30fps resolution mode due to more objects, decals, vegetation and crowds. However, there is no introduction of RT. The 60fps is also locked at 1700p (approx) to 4K PSSR, which is a big improvement over base PS5's 1080p in performance and even its 30fps mode which renders at 1440p.

name: The Elder Scrolls IV: OR
pageTitle: The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Remastered
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen global illumination and reflections with dynamic shadows

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1440p-2016p DRS (usually around 1620p) to 4K at a locked, but improperly paced 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1188p-1620p DRS to 4K at a very unstable 60fps that regularly falls below VRR window. Internal resolution/framerate dips lower when outside.

extraInfo: Pro performance mode has slightly improved draw distance/lighting than the base PS5 modes. Resolution and framerate in Pro performance mode are slightly increased compared to base PS5 (internal res can drop to 900p). There's no HDR and quality mode is improperly paced everywhere. No matter the console, performance gets worse if booting up from rest mode, cycling through saves or a continuous playthrough due to memory leak and needs a fresh start of the app to fix.

name: The Elders Scrolls Online
extraInfo: Pro uses variable rate shading to achieve 4K/60fps. This one mode combines the 2 modes seen on base PS5 (a 4K/30fps fidelity mode and 1440p/60fps performance mode that also had lower graphical settings). It's unclear if this is a native 4K, but this can be definitively answered when update 46 releases on June 2. Zenimax Online went very in-depth when the PS5/Series versions were released, going as far as comparing graphical settings like shadows and textures to a PC preset like 'ultra' or 'high'.  Hopefully they do the same for Pro nearer to release.

name: The Finals
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination
extraInfo: The only difference between the Pro and base PS5 is a resolution increase. General gameplay looks slightly sharper on Pro with a more stable 60fps due to the extra GPU horsepower. The RTGI quality remains the same and there is no option for 120fps.

name: The First Berserker: K

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1440p (likely) to 4K at a relatively stable 60fps. At least when it matters most (see extra info).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Around 1220p (approx) to 4K at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Quality mode holds a 60fps for the majority of combat. It can dip when lots of graphical effects are onscreen, but still stays above the 48fps VRR window. However, it can fall below that threshold in cutscenes. You can remove the framerate limit, but the game recommends that you keep it at 60fps or below.

name: The First Descendant
rtTypes: Ray traced shadows, reflections on translucent and opaque surfaces, ambient occlusion and radiance cache

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K PSSR at 30fps, or up to 60fps with frame generation on. Has all RT if turned on.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Same as fidelity mode, but aims for 40fps via a lower internal resolution before upscaling to 4K PSSR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p PSSR at 60fps, which is achieved more often with frame gen on. Has all RT except for RT shadows and translucent surface reflections.

extraInfo: One of the few Pro games to combine PSSR with AMD's FSR frame generation, whereas base PS5 uses FSR for upscaling. You can toggle both RT and frame generation on/off in all modes. Frame generation increases framerates, but isn't recommended as the base framerate is too low, resulting in too much input lag.

name: The Last Of Us Part I

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or around 70-90fps with VRR.

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps, 40fps with a 120Hz display, or 50-60fps with VRR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K TAA at a locked 60fps, or around 80-110fps with VRR.

extraInfo: The fidelity and performance modes are the same as on base PS5. The PSSR in Pro mode looks much sharper (especially foliage) than performance mode's TAA. There's also less noise/anti-aliasing in motion and improved SSR compared to both, but fidelity mode is still very close in image quality and some reflections can even look better. For VRR, there is usually around a 25fps advantage in comparison to the same mode being run on base PS5. PSSR beats the FSR implementation in the PC version and comes very close to DLSS.

name: The Last Of Us Part II

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or around 70-90fps with VRR.

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps, 40fps with a 120Hz display, or 50-60fps with VRR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K TAA at a locked 60fps, or around 80-110fps with VRR.

extraInfo: The fidelity and performance modes are the same as on base PS5. The PSSR in Pro mode looks much sharper (especially foliage) than performance mode's TAA. There's also less noise/anti-aliasing in motion and improved SSR compared to both, but fidelity mode is still very close in image quality and some reflections can even look better. For VRR, there is usually around a 25fps advantage in comparison to the same mode being run on base PS5. PSSR beats the FSR implementation in the PC version and comes very close to DLSS. Overall, Pro mode is around PC Ultra settings except for shadows which is a tier below.

name: Tides Of Annihilation
rtTypes: TBC
extraInfo: Despite releasing in 2026, EGG has confirmed a surprising amount about the Pro version via the PlayStation Blog. There will be a Pro exclusive 'enhanced mode' that utilizes PSSR to achieve all the expected Pro upgrades. This includes a higher resolution, RT, and improved image fidelity, all at 60fps. The most recent February 2025 trailer suggests an internal resolution of 576p-1080p DRS (1080p is far more often) and there's drops to around 35fps, but ToA's launch is around a year away leaving plenty of time for optimization. Using Pro footage for trailers so far from release does inspire confidence that it will get the optimization needed for a great 'enhanced mode'.

name: TopSpin 2K25
extraInfo: Pro now runs cutscenes/replays at 60fps instead of the 30fps on base PS5. This is the only upgrade as there's no resolution/gameplay differences between Pro and base PS5 (4K/60fps on both).

name: Truck Driver: TAD
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, ambient occlusion and global illumination

modes.name: fidelity pro 30fps
modes.description: Prioritizes resolution over framerate. Dynamic 4K PSSR at locked 30fps. Has improved shadows, lighting and draw distance compared to performance modes. Also has RTAO/GI/reflections.

modes.name: fidelity pro unlocked
modes.description: Prioritizes framerate over resolution. Dynamic 4K PSSR at 60/120fps. Has improved shadows, lighting and draw distance compared to performance modes. Also has RTAO/GI/reflections.

modes.name: performance RT pro
modes.description: Favors higher framerates (40/60/120fps) over resolution, which is 1080p-1440p DRS, but with RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Favors higher framerates (40/60/120fps) over resolution, which is 1080p-1440p DRS. No RT.

extraInfo: All modes use dynamic resolutions scaling. PSSR implementation produces much better assets, including moving ones like foliage, compared to TSR on base PS5. The resolution is also higher and there's better shadows regardless of mode. Pro also uses hardware accelerated RT reflections, RTAO and RTGI compared to the inferior software based RT on base PS5. Finally, the performance RT mode is exclusive to PS5 Pro.

name: UFL
extraInfo: Pro runs at a locked 60fps and native 4K. The display options are very similar to what you seen in FIFA/EA FC games. Therefore, there's no options for things like 120fps.

name: Undisputed
extraInfo: According to Steel City's patch notes, Pro has 'revamped lighting and improved gameplay graphics'. This likely means an 120fps option isn't in the cards. Despite the revamped lighting, Undisputed still doesn't support HDR - a feature the would drastically improve lighting with zero impact to performance, even on base PS5.

name: Until Dawn

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K at a stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Until Dawn allows you to render at 2.39:1 ratio for a more cinematic look with black bars but a wider viewing angle, or the usual 16:9. This doesn't affect resolution or framerate. Base PS5 also has a fidelity and performance mode that targets the same framerate but at lower resolutions.

name: War Thunder
extraInfo: Pro has DRS that can render up to 4K native, whereas base PS5 only runs at 1080p when aiming for 120fps. According to Gaijin, Pro also gets 'more improvements and additional optimization'. However, there's still a good amount of shimmer on assets like railings despite the up to 4x increase in resolution.

name: Wanderer: TFOF
extraInfo: There's currently no Pro patch, but Mighty Eyes's roadmap confirmed that one is coming sometime after July 2025. This will come with exclusive 'visual enhancements and effects to bring more fidelity and realism to each world', so expect more than just a resolution bump. A 60fps resolution mode that uses 'repositional' reprojection is also coming to both Pro and base PS5. Considering Pro's extra power and drop in framerate, resolution mode should be able to push PSVR2's screen to its maximum resolution of 2000 x 2040 per eye. Finally, it's currently unknown if an 120fps native mode will also be added with these enhancements.

name: Warframe
extraInfo: There's no strict quality/performance modes, nor can you go above 60fps. Instead, Warframe's menus are very PC-like in UI. For example, you can toggle graphical settings of aspects like particle quality and volumetric fog. You can also toggle PSSR on/off. If PSSR is on and all graphical settings so to their highest, the framerate is a basically locked 60fps. If toggled off/no upscaler used, it will rarely maintain 60fps, but will stay above the 48fps VRR window for the vast majority of gameplay.

name: Warhammer 40,000: DT
extraInfo: Base PS5 renders either performance mode 1440p/60fps (936p internal) or quality mode 4K/30fps (1440p internal). Pro renders at 4K/60fps (1270p internal) and looks sharper (especially in motion) than even base PS5 quality mode, despite the lower internal resolution, due to PSSR. The framerate on Pro is also more stable in areas where base PS5 isn't, but can become unstable at higher difficulty levels due to more enemies onscreen. The Pro version also runs most graphical settings equivalent to 'high' on PC.

name: Warhammer 40,000: RT

modes.name: graphics
modes.description: 4K native at a nearly locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p at 60fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 only has a performance mode as it can't render Rogue Trader at native 4K. Pro also has a much more stable framerate in both its modes compared to base PS5.

name: Warhammer 40,000: SM2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-2160p DRS to 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: speed
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a relatively stable 60fps. Drops to around 50fps in more chaotic scenes.

extraInfo: Base PS5 also has dynamic resolution scaling, but instead uses FSR2 to upscale its modes and have a lower base resolution before upscaling (e.g. 720p for speed mode). The result is a noticeably blurrier image compared to the Pro versions, especially in motion where PSSR excels. Pro also hits 60fps more often, though it's still not ideal as it can fall out of the VRR window.

name: Wolverine
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, shadows and ambient occlusion (based off Spider-Man 2)

modes.name: fidelity pro
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps/40fps for 60hz/120hz screens, or mid 50s with VRR. Highest quality RT (based off Spider-Man 2).

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or around 70fps with VRR. Base PS5 level of RT quality (based off Spider-Man 2).

extraInfo: Please note the above technical information is subject to change as Wolverine is still in development. However, this information is from leaked internal Insomniac documents and/or what Insomniac did with Spider-Man 2, so I decided it was worth including in the detailed games list to get a baseline of expectations.

name: World Of Warships: L
rtTypes: Hardware-based ray traced reflections
extraInfo: Pro runs at 4K/60fps which interestingly, is the same as the Series X version. Base PS5 only runs at 1440p/60fps, which means a 2x increase in resolution for Pro. There's also an RT toggle for hardware-based reflections, but the framerate is then capped at a locked 30fps.

name: Zenless Zone Zero
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections
extraInfo: Pro runs at a native 4K and relatively stable 60fps. At times when it dips under, it's still around 10 frames higher than base PS5. Pro also introduces ray traced reflections, ambient occlusion and improved diffuse lighting. You can however toggle RT off for a much more locked 60fps.

name: Zombie Derby
extraInfo: While both the base PS5 and Pro versions run at 120fps, base PS5 is limited to 1440p. Pro runs at 4K, which is 2x the resolution and with a nearly locked framerate.

name: Zombie Derby 2
extraInfo: While both the base PS5 and Pro versions run at 120fps, base PS5 is limited to 1440p. Pro runs at 4K, which is 2x the resolution and with a nearly locked framerate.

name: Zombie Derby: PS
extraInfo: While both the base PS5 and Pro versions run at 120fps, base PS5 is limited to 1440p. Pro runs at 4K, which is 2x the resolution and with a nearly locked framerate.
